newsitem.title: ITALY: New Italian law means 250,000 immigrants can stay.
newsitem.headline: New Italian law means 250,000 immigrants can stay.

text.p: Parliament approved a law on Thursday that will allow 250,000 previously illegal immigrants whose status had been thrown into doubt to stay in Italy.
The law was adopted in the Chamber of Deputies (lower house) by 261 votes to 126 with two abstentions.
It passed the Senate last month after the centre-left government used a confidence vote to sweep away an avalanche of blocking amendments, most of them from hard-right opponents.
The law covers only foreigners who registered with police under a measure issued as a temporary decree last November offering an amnesty to immigrants who legalised their status.
The measure, which had force of law for 60 days, was subsequently extended but a recent Constitutional Court ruling barred governments from rolling over decrees.
The ruling meant that without the law some 210,000 immigrants whose registration had been acknowledged and some 45,000 whose applications were pending technically could have been expelled from Italy.
Longer-term laws on immigration still have to be drawn up.
The hard-right National Alliance party, which wants tougher action to stop illegal immigrants entering Italy and to expel those who get in, criticised the new bill as a lost opportunity.

"If our cities become less safe, we'll know that the fault lies with a government which has missed a chance to establish more effective rules on expulsion," senior National Alliance politician Maurizio Gasparri said.
The separatist Northern League, which has a strong anti-immigrant slant, also attacked the bill.
Anti-racist and immigrant groups generally welcomed the measure.
Apart from allowing registered immigrants to stay, it contains provisions from the past decrees which allow police to expel foreigners without appeal if they are considered a threat to public order.
